trial_identification.studytitle: Symptoms, allergy and personal exposure to Plane Tree bioaerosols
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does exposure to Plane Tree bioaerosols lead to an increase in symptoms of respiratory allergy?

interventions.interventions: This is a preliminary, prospective study to investigate the exposure of Sydney residents to bioaerosols associated with the Plane Tree (Platanus x hybrida).No drugs or teatments will be used. We will be observing symptoms of respiratory allergies, including rhinitis and asthma. Subjective symptom scores will be recorded, as well as self-administered peak flow tests. Participants will be observed for 3 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Determination of the extent to which Plane Tree bioaerosols contribute to the respiratory symptoms of allergic Sydney residents.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Initially this will be measured over the 2006-2007 pollen season (August to November). The project is set to run from July 2006 to July 2007.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Participants must be allergic to Plane Tree pollen. Inclusion Criteria: Atopic to Platanus sp. by skin prick test.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Not atopic to Platanus sp. by skin prick test.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: We will determine the contribution of Plane Trees to the respiratory symptoms of inner-Sydney residents. We will measure the allergic symptoms of groups of patients over the Spring and Summer, while sampling air at 2 city locations and also specific locations related to exacerbations of symptoms (attacks) in individuals. The results of this study will help people manage their allergies, and provide information for policy-makers.
